chapter.fullItemName: Scenario: Management of suspected acute pancreatitis
chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of suspected acute pancreatitis
chapter.summary: Covers the primary care management of a person with suspected acute pancreatitis and includes information on secondary care investigations and management.

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Management of suspected acute pancreatitis

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected acute pancreatitis in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Admit urgently if the person has suspected acute pancreatitis, for further management.
  • Do not delay admission by taking blood samples or ordering imaging in primary care.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Secondary care management of acute pancreatitis
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Initial treatment of acute pancreatitis may include:
    • Resuscitation with intravenous fluids.
    • Supplemental oxygen (to maintain oxygenation of vital organs).
    • Pain relief.
    • Antibiotics for treatment of associated cholangitis or acute infections, such as chest infection or urinary tract infection.
    • Early nutritional support — oral feeding can commence in people with mild acute pancreatitis if there is no nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Enteral feeding is otherwise preferable and is possible in the majority of people. Parenteral feeding is reserved for people in whom enteral nutrition is not possible.
  • Initial investigations in secondary care are likely to include:
    • Lipase or amylase levels.
    • Assessment for prognostic features to identify those at risk of a potentially severe attack.
    • Imaging techniques, such as computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, or ultrasonography.
  • If the person has pancreatitis and organ dysfunction they will usually be managed in a high-dependency unit or intensive therapy unit.
  • If the person has acute pancreatitis caused by suspected or proven gallstones, management may include:
    • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography to relieve the obstruction, within 72 hours of the onset of pain, for those with cholangitis.
    • Cholecystectomy during the same admission. If the person has had a protracted course of severe disease, cholecystectomy may be delayed until clinically appropriate.

[Tenner, 2013; Johnson, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendation for urgent admission is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

  • Pancreatitis is a serious condition with a potential mortality rate of 10–25% [BMJ Best Practice, 2015], has a worsening prognosis if diagnosis is delayed, and is not amenable to treatment in primary care [Working Party of the British Society of Gastroenterology et al, 2005]. Therefore, urgent admission is needed in all people with suspected acute pancreatitis, without delay, for investigations and ongoing specialist management [Johnson, 2014].
